content:
Currently, we have docs#LinearMap.GeneralLinearGroup.congrLinearEquiv, docs#DirectSum.congrLinearEquiv, etc.
But I think these should be called foo.congrLinear instead since congr means equivalence.
We already have docs#SkewMonoidAlgebra.domCongrAlg and docs#TensorProduct.congrIsometry following this convention.

One way or another, something needs to change in order to keep the naming consistent.

(cc @Yaël Dillies)
Do we have any bundled equivalences that don't end in Equiv?

i believe in the CategoryTheory library there is precedent of just calling such (non-Eq) congr defs don't mention the resulting thing, e.g. CategoryTheory.Limits.kernel.congr...

which is to say, if anything i prefer congr over congrLinear since there is no such thing as "a linear"
looking into the situation a bit more, it looks like DirectSum.congr would be ambiguous, which leads me to the opinion that it's SkewMonoidAlgebra.domCongrAlg and the like which are in the wrong.
following my train of thought, TensorProduct.congrIsometry is doubly wrong, as docs#Isometry actually is a declaration which doesn't occur in the type.

following my train of thought, TensorProduct.congrIsometry is doubly wrong, as docs#Isometry actually is a declaration which doesn't occur in the type.

I think what happened there is since docs#TensorProduct.congr is a linear equivalence, we don't need to say TensorProduct.congrLinearIsometryEquiv since the linear equiv part is already in congr.

But maybe that's just me!
it's not unambiguous though, TensorProduct.congr could just as well be an AddEquiv
i think the name component congr is more about the shape of the lemma than about the types that occur in it, similar to trans, comp, refl, id, etc
Hmm, I see what you mean. Fair, fair. I'll change these two to congr(foo)Equiv later this week if everyone is in agreement then.
